misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads only three numeric values (v0, v1, t) as doubles instead of reading five integers as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to read three values (v0, v1, and t) for an average-acceleration calculation rather than five integers for a sum.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integers from the user, typically using nextInt (possibly in a loop) rather than three doubles.
symptoms: Prompt text requests 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers
Only three input values are read
nextDouble is used instead of nextInt
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this assignment and a different average-acceleration example or exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt and input logic to read five integers (using nextInt) from the user, either one by one or inside a loop.
related_concepts: Matching input format to problem specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, prompt string, and use of three nextDouble calls clearly correspond to a standard acceleration example, not to reading five integers.

evidence.note: Prompt and input statements are for three doubles (v0, v1, t) rather than five integers.

misconceptions.name: Implements average acceleration problem instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a physics average-acceleration calculation instead of summing the even numbers among five inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t and print that result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should sum only the even numbers out of five input integers and print that sum (e.g., 'Sum of even numbers: 14').
symptoms: Computation uses formula (v1 - v0) / t
No loop or accumulator for summing values
Output message refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied or adapted from a different textbook/example problem and did not adjust the code to this assignment’s requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the acceleration formula and instead introduce an integer accumulator variable, loop over the five inputs, add only the even ones to the sum, and print the sum with the required message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, formula, and printed message match a known average-acceleration example and do not address even-number summation.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Code calculates average acceleration and prints it, rather than summing even integers and printing that sum.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding/Substitution of Assignment Goal

None of the procedural requirements for the assignment were met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code is the solution to the current assignment, or the student confused this assignment with a previous or different task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read 5 integer values, analyze each one to determine if it is even, and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.

Code calculates acceleration.
No loop structure is present.
No modulo operation is used to check for evenness.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about which assignment file to submit, or complete negligence in reading the prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment prompt and discard the current code. Focus on the requirements: 1. Use a loop to handle 5 inputs. 2. Use the modulo operator (%) to check for evenness. 3. Use an accumulator variable to store the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves an entirely different problem (kinematics/acceleration) and shares no requirements with the assigned task (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) for a kinematics problem, not 5 integers for the sum of even numbers problem.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs

misconceptions.name: Missing loop for multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: Student did not use any loop structure to process multiple input values; instead hardcoded individual variable reads
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading multiple inputs can be done without a loop by declaring separate variables
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When reading multiple values (especially when the count is known), use a loop structure (for/while) to efficiently read and process them. This avoids code duplication and scales to any number of inputs

No for or while loop in the code
Code only reads 3 values instead of 5
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not recognize the pattern of using loops for repeated operations, or submitted code from a different problem context
